thread.title: Here's what Eli Manning accomplished while rallying the Giants past the San Francisco 49ers
thread.title_full: Here's what Eli Manning accomplished while rallying the Giants past the San Francisco 49ers | NJ.com

author: Jordan Raanan | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Here's what Eli Manning accomplished while rallying the Giants past the San Francisco 49ers
text:
EAST RUTHERFORD ‐ When the Giants needed it most Sunday night against the San Francisco 49ers at MetLife Stadium, they turned to their star quarterback. Eli Manning has done some incredible things throughout his career, and this one ranks right up there with the best of them. Manning threw the game-winning touchdown pass with 21 seconds remaining to tight end Larry Donnell in a 30-27 victory over the San Francisco 49ers.
"He's our guy," coach Tom Coughlin said. "He knows it."
Manning had a monster effort working with a decimated receiving corps. He put the team on his shoulders.
Just how big an effort was it? Here's a look at what Manning accomplished during the contest:
• 27th game-winning drive (regular season) ‐ It was Manning's first game-winning drive since Dec. 22, 2013.
RELATED : What this win says about the Giants
• 41 completions ‐ Easily a career high. His previous best was 34 against the Tennessee Titans in 2010. They were also a new Giants record. Phil Simms completed 40 passes against the Bengals in 1985.
• 54 attempts ‐ Also a new career high. He had thrown 53 passes in a game three times, including the season finale last year against the Eagles.
• 441 yards passing ‐ The third-best total of his career. He threw for 510 against the Bucs in 2012 and 450 yards against the Cowboys in 2013.
• 110.2 QB Rating ‐ It was the second time this season Manning had a QB rating over 110.
• 15 consecutive passes completed ‐ He didn't throw an incompletion for the final 13:08 of the third quarter and the first 9:06 of the fourth quarter.
• 41,172 passing yards (career) ‐ After throwing for 441 yards he passes Kerry Collin (40,922) for 12th all-time. Next up: Dan Fouts (43,040).
• 172nd consecutive start ‐ It's easily the longest active streak in the NFL.
• 102nd career victory (regular season and playoffs) ‐ He passed Simms, who had 101 victories as the Giants starting quarterback.
